description: Image manifest for Building Intelligent Textbooks with AI

instructions.adding_images: 1. Place color version in color/ directory, 2. Place B&W version in bw/ directory, 3. Add entry to images array below
instructions.naming: Use lowercase with hyphens, e.g., five-level-model.png
instructions.formats: PNG preferred for diagrams, JPEG for photos

images.title: The Five Levels of Intelligent Textbooks
images.description: Stairstep diagram showing five levels of intelligent textbooks from bottom to top: Level 1 (Static Textbooks) in red, Level 2 (Interactive Content) in blue, Level 3 (Adaptive Textbooks) in teal, Level 4 (Chatbot Integration) in purple, and Level 5 (Autonomous AI) in yellow. Levels 3-5 are enclosed in a dashed red box labeled 'Highly Regulated Textbooks' indicating the privacy threshold.
images.section: A Five-Level Model of Intelligent Textbooks
images.altText: Stairstep diagram showing five levels of intelligent textbook capability from static to autonomous AI

images.title: Autonomous Vehicles vs Intelligent Textbooks Comparison
images.description: Side-by-side comparison table showing SAE J3016 vehicle automation levels (0-5) alongside corresponding intelligent textbook levels. Left column shows vehicle levels from No/Driver Assistance to Full Automation. Right column shows textbook equivalents from Static Textbook to Autonomous AI Textbook. A horizontal line marks the 'Data Collection Threshold' between levels 2 and 3.
images.section: A Five-Level Model of Intelligent Textbooks
images.altText: Comparison table of SAE autonomous vehicle levels and intelligent textbook levels

images.title: AI Task Completion Time Horizons
images.description: Scatter plot with logarithmic y-axis showing AI task completion time horizons from 2019 to 2025. Y-axis ranges from 3 seconds to 16.7 hours. Blue dots represent 50% success horizon measurements, with a shaded 95% confidence interval band. Shows exponential growth from ~3 seconds in 2019 to several hours by 2025.
images.altText: Logarithmic chart showing exponential growth in AI task completion duration from 2019 to 2025

images.title: Projecting AI Task Completion to 2030
images.description: Scatter plot projecting AI task completion horizons from 2019 to 2030. Y-axis shows task duration from minutes to 694 days. Green dots represent frontier models, gray dots non-frontier models. Dashed trend line shows 7-month doubling rate extending to nearly 2 years by 2030. Subtitle asks 'How long will AI models work on tasks?'
images.altText: Chart projecting AI task completion capability growth to 2030 with 7-month doubling trend
images.source: Based on METR research data with projections

images.title: MMLU Benchmark: AI Model Performance Over Time
images.description: Line chart showing Massive Multitask Language Understanding (MMLU) benchmark scores from 2020 to 2025. Y-axis shows percentage from 40% to 90%, with horizontal blue line at 89.9% marking 'Human Level'. Multiple colored lines track different model families: GPT series (green shades), Claude series (yellow/gold), Gemini (red), LLaMA/Llama (blue), PaLM (cyan), Mistral (pink), and Grok (purple). Shows rapid convergence toward human-level performance by 2025.
images.altText: Chart showing AI models approaching human-level performance on MMLU benchmark from 2020-2025

images.title: Sample Learning Graph: Arithmetic
images.description: Simple directed graph showing arithmetic concept dependencies. Orange 'Numbers' node is the foundation. Brown operation nodes (Addition, Multiplication, Division, Subtraction) connect with labeled 'DEPENDS_ON' edges. Blue 'Arithmetic' node connects to all operations. Shows hierarchical learning path from numbers through operations.
images.section: The Role of a Learning Graph
images.altText: Directed graph showing concept dependencies for basic arithmetic operations

images.title: Complex Learning Graph: Circuits Course
images.description: Large-scale interactive learning graph viewer showing 300 concepts and 627 edges for an electrical engineering circuits course. Left sidebar shows category filters with node counts: Foundation Concepts, Circuit Analysis, Passive Components, Transient Analysis, AC Fundamentals, AC Power, Frequency Response, Filters, Operational Amplifiers, and Signal Analysis. Statistics panel displays: Visible Nodes: 300, Visible Edges: 627, Foundational: 4. Main area shows force-directed graph with color-coded nodes organized by category and directed edges showing concept dependencies.
images.section: The Learning Graph as the Core Data Structure
images.altText: Interactive learning graph viewer showing 300 circuit concepts with 627 dependency edges organized by category

images.title: Knowledge Spaces: Zone of Learning
images.description: Conceptual diagram illustrating personalized knowledge spaces and the zone of proximal learning. Shows a directed graph of concepts with three color-coded states: green nodes represent Known Concepts (already mastered), yellow nodes represent Ready to Learn Concepts (within the Zone of Learning marked by dashed vertical lines), and red nodes represent Unknown Concepts (depend on unmastered prerequisites). Demonstrates how adaptive systems identify the optimal next concepts for each student based on their current mastery state.
images.altText: Knowledge space diagram showing mastered concepts in green, ready-to-learn concepts in yellow, and unknown concepts in red

images.title: Intelligent Textbook Generation Workflow
images.description: Comprehensive flowchart showing the textbook generation process. Top row (colored boxes): Course Description → 2001 Bloom Taxonomy → Concept Enumeration → Concept Dependencies → Learning Graph, with Concept Taxonomy branching up. Middle row (light blue): Chapters & Sections, Glossary of Terms, Word Cloud, FAQ, Summaries. Bottom row (green): Figures/Diagrams/Charts, Interactive Infographics, MicroSims, Graphic Novel Stories, Assessments. Arrows show dependencies between stages.
images.altText: Flowchart showing the complete intelligent textbook generation workflow from course description to final content

images.title: Bloom's Taxonomy: RUAAEC Pyramid
images.description: Classic six-level pyramid showing Bloom's Taxonomy cognitive levels. From bottom to top: Remember (purple), Understand (blue), Apply (green), Analyze (yellow), Evaluate (orange), Create (red). Title includes 'RUAAEC' mnemonic. Each level is a distinct colored band with white text labels.
images.altText: Pyramid diagram showing six levels of Bloom's Taxonomy from Remember to Create

images.title: Bloom's Taxonomy Action Verb Wheel
images.description: Interactive circular wheel diagram showing Bloom's Taxonomy with action verbs for each level. Six colored sections arranged clockwise: Remember (blue) with verbs like recall, locate, identify; Understand (green) with interpret, explain, summarize; Apply (teal) with demonstrate, implement, solve; Analyze (orange) with differentiate, examine, organize; Evaluate (pink/magenta) with judge, validate, critique; Create (purple) with design, produce, invent. Center shows 'Click a verb to learn more'. Random Verb button at bottom.
images.altText: Interactive wheel showing action verbs organized by Bloom's Taxonomy levels

images.title: Learning Graph: Economics Course
images.description: Large-scale interactive learning graph viewer showing ~200 economics concepts. Left sidebar shows category filters with checkboxes: Foundation Concepts (18), Microeconomics (42), Market Structures (11), Public Economics (21), Macroeconomics (20), Money and Banking (13), Economic Policy (17), International Trade (13), Personal Finance (17), Investment (10), Digital Economy (13), Critical Thinking (5). Main area displays force-directed graph with color-coded nodes and dependency arrows.
images.altText: Interactive learning graph viewer showing 200 economics concepts organized by category

images.title: Concept Dependencies Graph for Programming
images.description: Interactive learning graph showing programming concept dependencies. Left panel shows legend: Edge types (REQUIRES solid line for hard prerequisite, SUPPORTS dashed for soft), Node colors (blue default, orange selected, green prerequisite, pink leads-to). Main graph shows concepts: Variables, Data Types, Operators at top flowing to Expressions, then to Conditionals, Loops, Functions, then to Arrays, Objects, Recursion, and finally to Algorithms and Data Structures. Right panel shows selected concept details.
images.altText: Interactive graph showing programming concept dependencies from variables to algorithms

images.title: Glossary of Terms: MkDocs Material Format
images.description: Screenshot of a glossary page from an intelligent textbook built with MkDocs Material theme. Header shows 'Automating Instructional Design' with search bar. Left sidebar navigation includes chapters, MicroSims, Stories, Learning Graph, FAQ, Glossary (highlighted), and more. Main content shows 'Glossary of Terms' with ISO 11179 compliant definitions. Right sidebar shows alphabetical table of contents. Entries shown include A/B Testing and Ability-Based Feedback with definitions and examples.
images.altText: Screenshot showing glossary page format in MkDocs Material intelligent textbook

images.title: Chart Type Selection Guide
images.description: Six-panel reference card showing when to use different chart types. Top row: Line Chart (green, trends over time, e.g. stock prices), Bar Chart (blue, comparing categories, e.g. sales by region), Pie/Doughnut (orange, parts of whole max 6, e.g. market share). Bottom row: Scatter Plot (purple, showing correlations, e.g. height vs weight), Function Plot (cyan, mathematical functions, e.g. y=sin(x)), Radar Chart (red, multi-variable comparison, e.g. skill profiles). Each panel shows icon, use case, example, and recommended library.
images.altText: Reference guide showing six chart types with when to use each

images.title: MicroSim Design Philosophy: Three Principles
images.description: Venn diagram with three overlapping circles showing the core principles of MicroSim design. Top circle (blue): Simplicity. Bottom left (green): Accessibility. Bottom right (peach): AI Generation. Center intersection labeled 'MicroSims' where all three principles meet. Illustrates that effective MicroSims balance simplicity, accessibility, and AI-generatability.
images.altText: Venn diagram showing MicroSims at intersection of Simplicity, Accessibility, and AI Generation

images.title: MicroSim Technology Stack Architecture
images.description: Layered architecture diagram showing MicroSim technology stack. Top layer: MicroSim box with arrow to xAPI then to Learner Record Store (database icon). Below MicroSim: JavaScript Libraries (p5.js, vis.js etc.), then HTML5/ECMAScript/Canvas, then Web Browser (Chrome, Firefox), and at bottom Drawing Libraries (WebGL, WebGPU). Shows how MicroSims connect to learning analytics through xAPI.
images.altText: Layered architecture diagram showing MicroSim technology stack from browser to LRS

images.title: MicroSim Layout: Drawing and Control Regions
images.description: Annotated wireframe showing standard MicroSim layout with two regions. Top region (light blue background with blue border): Drawing area showing sine wave, labeled 'Top drawing region does not contain interactive controls'. Annotations show 'Blue border and light blue background indicate interactive graphic' and 'Fixed Height'. Bottom region (white): Control area with Amplitude, Period, Phase sliders. Annotations show 'Lower control region contains interactive simulation controls', 'Responsive Width', and 'Horizontal sliders resize when container changes'.
images.altText: Annotated diagram showing MicroSim layout with drawing region above and control region below

images.title: MicroSim Example: Bouncing Ball Simulation
images.description: Simple p5.js MicroSim showing a bouncing ball simulation. Light blue canvas area with title 'Bouncing Ball Simulation'. Blue circular ball shown mid-canvas. Bottom control region has Start button and Speed slider set to 3. Demonstrates minimal MicroSim with single animation and one control parameter.
images.altText: Simple bouncing ball MicroSim with start button and speed slider

images.title: MicroSim Example: Projectile Motion
images.description: Physics MicroSim showing projectile motion with cannon. Light blue sky background with cannon at bottom left showing 58° angle. Multiple dashed parabolic trajectories show different launch paths. Control region has Angle slider (58°), Power slider (10.5), Fire button, and Reset button. Demonstrates physics simulation with multiple parameters.
images.altText: Projectile motion MicroSim with adjustable angle and power controls

images.title: MicroSim Example: Pythagorean Theorem
images.description: Geometry MicroSim demonstrating the Pythagorean theorem. Shows right triangle with colored squares on each side: green square on side a (100), blue square on side b (100), pink square on hypotenuse c (141). Formula c² = a² + b² shown top right. Values displayed: a²=10000, b²=10000, c²=20000. Sliders for Side a and Side b at bottom, with Hide Squares and Reset buttons.
images.altText: Interactive Pythagorean theorem visualization with adjustable triangle sides

images.title: MicroSim Example: Least Squares Regression
images.description: Statistics MicroSim showing least squares regression line fitting. Grid background with multiple data points (purple and green dots). Blue regression line passes through points. Colored squares (red, yellow, cyan, green) visualize squared residuals - the errors being minimized. Sliders for Slope (0.5) and Intercept (2) allow manual line adjustment to understand optimization.
images.altText: Least squares regression MicroSim showing residual squares and adjustable line

images.title: MicroSim Example: Expression Parts Explorer
images.description: Algebra MicroSim for teaching expression components. Shows expression '22y + 19y - 5b² + 22' with color-coded parts: coefficients (22, 19, 5) in different colors, variables (y, b) highlighted, constant (22) in yellow with 'Constant' tooltip. Right panel shows Analysis: Terms: 4, Operators: 3, Coefficients: 22, 19, 5, Variables: y, b, Constant: 22. Controls include New Expression, Quiz Mode toggle, complexity dropdown, and checkboxes for showing coefficients/variables/constants.
images.altText: Interactive algebra expression explorer showing terms, coefficients, and variables

images.title: MicroSim Example: Barnsley's Fern Fractal
images.description: Fractal MicroSim generating Barnsley's Fern using iterated function system. Green fractal fern pattern rendered with 50,000 iterations. Controls at bottom: Iterations slider (50,000), Scale slider (80), Leaf Angle slider (4.5°), Curl slider (1.5), and Black Spleenwort Preset checkbox. Demonstrates mathematical art through chaos game algorithm.
images.altText: Barnsley's Fern fractal MicroSim with adjustable parameters

images.title: MicroSim Example: Conway's Game of Life
images.description: Cellular automaton MicroSim showing Conway's Game of Life. Grid of cells with blue dots representing live cells in various patterns (gliders, oscillators, still lifes). Controls at bottom: Start, Step, Reset buttons and Speed slider (10). Demonstrates emergent behavior from simple rules.
images.altText: Conway's Game of Life cellular automaton with control buttons

images.title: MicroSim Example: Letter Matching Game
images.description: Educational game MicroSim for learning letter case matching. Two rows of letter tiles: UPPERCASE row (blue borders) shows A, H, F, C, G, E; lowercase row (orange borders) shows a, c, f, g, h, e in scrambled order. Score: 0/6, Attempts: 0 shown top right. Controls: New Game button and Pairs slider (6). Gamification example for early literacy.
images.altText: Letter matching game with uppercase and lowercase pairs

images.title: MicroSim Example: Solar Cell Charging
images.description: Energy systems MicroSim showing solar panel charging battery. Scene shows blue sky with yellow sun, clouds, solar panel array on left, battery (green charge level) in center connected by wires with red electron dots, and light bulb on right. Controls: Time slider (12:00 PM), Sunshine slider (70%), Power Drain slider (50%). Demonstrates renewable energy concepts.
images.altText: Solar cell charging simulation with sun, battery, and power controls

images.title: MicroSim Example: FFT Microphone Visualizer
images.description: Audio analysis MicroSim showing real-time FFT frequency spectrum from microphone input. Bar chart displays frequency bins from 0 to 4.0k Hz on x-axis, amplitude on y-axis. Bars colored in rainbow gradient from blue (low frequencies) through green, yellow, to red (high frequencies). Peak visible around 1.3k Hz. Controls: Stop button and Max Freq slider (4.0k Hz).
images.altText: FFT audio spectrum visualizer showing frequency analysis of microphone input

images.title: MicroSim Example: Tragedy of the Commons
images.description: Economics/systems thinking MicroSim demonstrating tragedy of the commons. Grid shows pasture with cells colored: green (healthy grass), gray (degraded), purple (overgrazed). Cow emoji icons scattered across grid representing grazing cattle. Control: Number of Cows slider (50), Start/Stop and Reset buttons. Visualizes how individual rational behavior leads to collective resource depletion.
images.altText: Tragedy of the commons simulation showing grazing cows and pasture degradation

images.title: MicroSim Example: Unix Command Syntax Guide
images.description: Computing education MicroSim teaching Unix command structure. Shows example command 'find /photos -name "*.png" -o -name "*.jpg" -size +1M -mtime -7' with color-coded parts and arrows: Command (blue), Path (orange), Name filter (green), Size filter (purple), Time filter (pink). Legend explains: Command = program to run, Options = start with -, Arguments = inputs. Dropdown selects different example commands.
images.altText: Unix command syntax visualizer with color-coded command parts

images.title: MicroSim Example: Causal Loop Diagram
images.description: Systems thinking MicroSim showing causal loop diagram for intelligent textbook adoption. Nodes in blue boxes: Global MicroSims, Intelligent Textbooks, Teachers Aware of MicroSims, Demand for Textbooks, Demand for MicroSims. Green arrows with + signs show reinforcing relationships. Red 'R' circles mark two reinforcing feedback loops. Demonstrates systems dynamics visualization.
images.altText: Causal loop diagram showing reinforcing feedback loops in textbook adoption

images.title: MicroSim Example: College Loan Payback Calculator
images.description: Financial literacy MicroSim for understanding student loan costs. Shows calculated results: Total Loan Amount $200,000, Time to Pay Off 64 years 8 months, Total Interest Paid $653,123, Total Amount Paid $853,123. Stacked bar shows Principal (blue) vs Interest (coral) portions. Sliders: Years in College (4), Cost per Year ($50,000), Interest Rate (6.5%), Monthly Payment ($1,100). Demonstrates compound interest impact.
images.altText: College loan calculator showing principal vs interest over repayment period

images.title: MicroSim Example: US State Quality of Life Index
images.description: Geographic data visualization MicroSim using Leaflet maps. US map with states colored by quality of life index (8 metrics vs national average): dark green (8/8 best) through yellow (4/8 avg) to dark red (0/8 worst). Minnesota highlighted showing popup with details: Excellent (8/8), metrics include Personal Income (#11, $58,234), Poverty Rate (#6, 8.5%), Education (#8, 37.3%), Life Expectancy (#5, 79.8 yrs), etc. Legend shows color scale.
images.altText: Interactive US map showing state quality of life scores with hover details

images.title: MicroSim Example: Historical Timeline
images.description: Timeline visualization MicroSim using vis-timeline library showing McCreary Family Heritage from Kingdom of Scotland to American Settlement. Timeline spans 800-1900 with filter buttons: All Events, McCreary Origins, Scottish History, Irish History, Events in America. Events shown as colored bars: Kingdom of Scotland Established, Norman Conquest, Battle of Bannockburn, Ulster Plantation, etc. Popup shows detailed event description when hovering.
images.altText: Interactive historical timeline with filterable event categories

images.title: The Privacy Threshold: Level 3 Inflection Point
images.description: Vertical bar chart showing data collection intensity across five textbook levels. X-axis: Level 1 Static through Level 5 Autonomous. Y-axis: Data Collection Intensity from None to Very High. Level 1 has no bar, Level 2 shows minimal (green), Levels 3-5 show escalating bars (yellow, orange, red). Vertical dashed red line marks 'Privacy Threshold' between Level 2 and 3. Subtitle: 'Data collection requirements escalate dramatically at Level 3+'.
images.altText: Bar chart showing data collection requirements increasing dramatically at Level 3 and above

images.title: Adaptive Assessment: Learning Graph Update
images.description: Interactive learning graph showing personal mastery state for algebra concepts. Legend shows color coding: Gray (Unknown), Green (Mastered), Orange (Ready to Learn), Red (Incorrect), Purple (Learning Goal). Graph displays ~17 concepts from Number at top through Multi-Step at bottom. Shows 5/17 concepts mastered. Includes 'Click a node to assess' instruction and Reset button.
images.altText: Learning graph with nodes colored by mastery status showing adaptive assessment in action

images.title: Learning Graph: Foundation to Goal Progression
images.description: Abstract learning graph showing concept progression levels. Blue nodes (Foundation 1, 2) on left, yellow nodes (Level 2.1, 2.2) in middle, red/coral nodes (Level 3.1, 3.2, 3.3) next, and green goal nodes (Goal 1, 2, 3) on right. Numbers in parentheses indicate concept count. Colored arrows show dependencies flowing left to right from foundations through intermediate levels to goals.
images.altText: Diagram showing learning progression from foundation concepts through intermediate levels to learning goals

images.title: Learning Standards Ecosystem
images.description: Network diagram showing relationships between learning technology standards. Nodes include: IEEE LTSC (orange), IEEE LOM (green), LTI (yellow), xAPI (blue), LRS (blue), LMS (green), Caliper Analytics (orange), CLR (blue), Intelligent Textbook (purple), FERPA (red), GDPR (red). Labeled edges show relationships: 'defines', 'connects', 'describes', 'must comply', etc. Shows how xAPI and LRS connect to intelligent textbooks and regulatory frameworks.
images.altText: Network diagram showing relationships between learning technology standards and regulations

images.title: AI Flywheel for Continuous Improvement
images.description: Circular diagram showing the AI improvement flywheel with four stages connected by arrows: Data (green, top) → 'Used to Create' → Model (blue, right) → 'Used to Create' → Prediction (orange, bottom) → 'Generates' → Feedback (purple, left) → 'Provides More' → Data. Illustrates the virtuous cycle of AI improvement through usage and feedback.
images.altText: Circular diagram showing the AI flywheel cycle: Data, Model, Prediction, Feedback

images.title: Predicted Rates of AI Improvement
images.description: Line chart showing four possible AI capability growth scenarios over time. X-axis: Time with 'Now' marked. Y-axis: AI Capability. Four curves: Red 'Peaking & Declining' (rises then falls), Green 'Flattening' (levels off), Blue 'Slow Linear Growth' (steady rise), Purple 'Exponential Growth' (dramatic upward curve). Purple exponential line dramatically exceeds others by chart end.
images.altText: Chart comparing four possible AI growth scenarios: declining, flat, linear, and exponential

images.title: Moore's Law: Transistor Count (1965-2025)
images.description: Scatter plot showing transistor count growth from 1965 to 2025 on logarithmic y-axis (10^2 to 10^12). Blue dots represent CPUs, green dots GPUs, orange dots SoCs, red dots AI chips. Dashed blue trend line shows Moore's Law prediction. Data points follow the exponential trend remarkably well over 60 years, demonstrating sustained doubling approximately every two years.
images.altText: Logarithmic chart showing 60 years of transistor count growth following Moore's Law

images.title: Google Analytics: Active Users and Events
images.description: Screenshot of Google Analytics 4 dashboard showing real-time analytics for an intelligent textbook. Displays active users over time, event counts, page views, and user engagement metrics. Shows typical analytics data useful for monitoring textbook usage patterns.
images.altText: Google Analytics dashboard showing active users and events for an intelligent textbook

images.title: MicroSim Embeddings: 2D Similarity Map
images.description: Two-dimensional visualization of MicroSim embeddings projected into 2D space using dimensionality reduction. images.altText: 2D scatter plot showing MicroSim embeddings with similar simulations clustered together

images.altText: Faceted search interface showing filters and MicroSim results

images.title: Course Mascot Example: Meet Gyra
images.description: Example of course mascot integration showing Gyra, a two-wheel self-balancing robot. Illustration shows diverse students gathered around Gyra in a classroom setting. Description explains Gyra's role: she wobbles, overcorrects, and tips over - not because she's broken, but because physics is unforgiving. Students take on the role of Gyra's control engineer throughout the course.
images.altText: Illustration of Gyra robot mascot with students in classroom, with description of her role
images.source: Screenshot from intelligent textbook features page

images.title: Effort Levels: Manual vs GenAI vs Skills
images.description: Comparison table showing effort levels for textbook creation tasks across three approaches: Human Time (manual), With GenAI, and With GenAI Skills. Levels range from Trivial (config change) through Low (single file), Medium (multiple files), High (significant generation), to Very High (complex integration). Shows dramatic time reduction when using AI skills.
images.altText: Table comparing effort levels for manual work vs GenAI vs GenAI skills
images.source: Screenshot from intelligent textbook features page

images.title: Multi-Hop Query Performance: Relational vs Graph (Linear Scale)
images.description: Line chart comparing query response time between RDBMS (JOIN operations) and Graph DB (index-free adjacency) as relationship hops increase from 1 to 6. Linear y-axis shows time in milliseconds/minutes. RDBMS performance degrades exponentially, reaching 13+ minutes at 5 hops with queries timing out beyond 4 hops. Graph DB maintains near-constant performance throughout. Based on healthcare dependency analysis with 100,000 patient records.
images.altText: Linear scale chart showing RDBMS query time exploding while graph DB stays constant as hops increase

images.title: Multi-Hop Query Performance: Relational vs Graph (Log Scale)
images.description: Line chart comparing query response time between RDBMS and Graph DB on logarithmic y-axis, making performance differences visible at all hop counts. Shows RDBMS starting at ~15ms for 1 hop and growing to ~1000 seconds at 5 hops. Graph DB grows from ~3ms to ~20ms over the same range. The 1-second threshold line highlights when queries become unacceptably slow for interactive use.
images.altText: Logarithmic scale chart showing orders-of-magnitude difference between RDBMS and graph DB query performance
